Award.AwardTitle: LTREB Renewal: Long-term Research on Environmental Gender Determination in a Model System (Chrysemys)
Award.AbstractNarration:
In several major groups of vertebrates, environmental temperatures experienced during embryonic development determine offspring gender. Temperature-dependent gender determination will be addressed with a multi-year field study of a wild population of the painted turtle, Chrysemys picta. The project will investigate several aspects of this unusual phenomenon: (1) the impact of long-term climatic variation on population structure, particularly the ratio of males to females, (2) the effect of lifetime patterns of nesting behavior on offspring gender ratio, and (3) climatic effects on variation in predator numbers and differential predation on nests, and hence shifts in population gender ratio. A team of student researchers will record nesting date and vegetation cover over nests, follow females across years to evaluate nesting behavior, monitor nests to investigate the influence of predators on offspring recruitment, and relate these data to information on climate and human habitat use.

The findings of this research will have important implications for the impacts of climate change and human habitat use on the biology and conservation of species with this gender determination system. This long-term research program will also continue to provide extensive first-hand and on-line educational opportunities for numerous students, including many underrepresented minorities and women, and the public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Genetic factors at conception generally determine whether an individual becomes male or female. Yet, in a few groups of animals, temperatures during embryonic development permanently determine sex. This unusual system (known as TSD), where genetically-identical individuals can become either sex, is a model for understanding environmental effects on biological traits, but how TSD works in nature is not entirely clear. Addressing this question is urgent given the fast rate of environmental change and the fact that most species with TSD are already imperiled globally.

This long-term project investigated significant aspects of TSD, focusing on a wild population of painted turtles. This project emphasized three issues: (1) the impacts of climate variation on population structure, especially the numbers of males and females (=sex ratio), (2) the influence of maternal nesting behavior on offspring sex ratio, and (3) the effects of climate variation on nest survival and offspring quality, and ensuing shifts in population composition. Teams of students examined these issues based on the principle that how populations respond to changing environmental conditions is crucial to long-term persistence.

This project established that populations with TSD are sensitive to fairly small temperature shifts from the long-term average. For example, if the standard July air temperature changed only 3 degrees Fahrenheit (F), offspring sex ratio in the study population would shift from the typical one male for every one female to a situation where offspring of mainly one sex would be produced. Such a dramatic shift in sex ratio is almost certainly unfavorable.

Altering nesting behavior is the most likely means for populations with TSD to respond to temperature changes. Nests constructed in shadier sites earlier in the season are cooler and more likely to produce male offspring than nests located in sunnier sites later in the season. These two traits seem to shift with severity of winter conditions, but experimental manipulations of winter temperatures and adult sex ratios did not alter nesting behavior accordingly, so explanations for these patterns remain a mystery. Regardless, such shifts in nesting behavior would be insufficient to fully reduce biases in sex ratio caused by a 3 F change in average July air temperature, which climatologists anticipate in just the next 20 years.

Changing environments can also indirectly affect sex ratio and offspring quality in populations with TSD. Intensity of raccoon predation varies annually, ranging from 20-100% of turtle nests destroyed. Flooding during nesting season further contributes to suppressing hatching success. Notably, annual nest predation ranged from 84-100% since 2008 (the average was about 50% before then) and elevated frequency of river flooding has further decimated recruitment of turtle offspring. Although increasingly rare, when nest predation is modest and flooding absent in a year that also experiences typical July air temperatures, an influx of new adult females enters the turtle population about 6 years later. Predation intensity and environmental severity therefore interact to strongly shape the structure of populations with TSD.

Such research results continue to be disseminated widely in talks, publications, and data archives. Among other practical outcomes, these findings provide guidance for improved conservation strategies for populations with TSD. The considerable information collected also has been incorporated into a computerized database that allows users to explore the data to address emerging scientific questions.

This project generated additional broader impacts. In the past 7 years alone, 78 students (many involved for multiple years), from high school to undergraduate to graduate and beyond, contributed to the extensive research, education, and outreach activities. Nearly every participant has sought higher education in science, with many then enrolling in advanced degree programs in health, law, education, and science. Moreover, 66 of these students were women, underrepresented minorities, and/or persons with disabilities, thereby contributing importantly to diversifying the scientifically-literate workforce.

People love turtles, sanctioning this project as an effective means both for agreeably conveying basic scientific principles and for developing practical solutions to environmental issues. The project participants productively interacted with members of the public daily at the field site as well as through planned outreach events with K-12 teachers, Boy Scout troops, and children at a local library.
